awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X:RES: Collaborative Research: Data Science Frontiers in Climate Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the factors that determine regional climate variability and change is a challenge with important implications for the economy, security, and environmental sustainability of many regions around the globe. Our understanding and modeling of the large-scale dynamics of the Earth climate system and associated regional-scale climate variability significantly affects our ability to predict and mitigate climatic extremes and hazards. Earth observations and climate model outputs are witnessing an unprecedented increase in data volume, creating new opportunities to advance climate science but also leading to new data science challenges that must be addressed using tools from mathematics, statistics, and computer science. This project focuses on two central challenges at the heart of modern data-enabled climate science: (1) Increasing the predictive capacity of subseasonal forecasts by discovering and quantifying the sources of (un)predictability, including known and emergent climate modes and their interactions and non-stationarities; and (2) Understanding and quantifying the intricate space-time dynamics of the climate system to provide guidance for climate model assessment and regional forecasting.  This project brings together an interdisciplinary team that combines expertise in both hydroclimate science and statistical machine learning to create new platforms for climate diagnostics and prognostics.  The broader impacts of an enhanced knowledge of the climate system and robust and accurate seasonal forecasts have wide-ranging implications for society as a whole. For example, better seasonal forecasts will allow water resource managers to make sustainable decisions for water allocation.

This TRIPODS+CLIMATE project will develop novel machine learning and network estimation methodologies for analyzing the climate system over a range of space and time scales, to understand climate modes of variability and change and to explore their predictive ability for regional hydroclimatology. The two main objectives of this project are the following.  Objective 1: Develop novel classification and regression tools that account for highly-correlated features or covariates, nonlinear interaction terms in high-dimensional settings, and nonstationarity in climate observations. These tools will be used to improve seasonal-to-subseasonal forecasts of regional precipitation using multidimensional climate modes and feature vectors in the presence of evolving dynamics and nonstationarities. Objective 2: Develop network identification methods that leverage recent advances in machine learning and statistics and that can account for the nonstationarity and limited timeframe of climate data. The network representation will be used to analyze the structure and dynamics of the learned dependencies to contextualize and interpret them physically, and to quantify changing patterns in climate modes and their regional predictive capacity.  Emphasis will be placed on the western Pacific dynamics where an interhemispheric bi-directional connection has recently been discovered, promising earlier and more accurate seasonal-to-subseasonal forecasts in the southwestern US and other parts of the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Earth’s climate is a highly complex, non-linear system which plays a vital role in supporting human life and ecosystems on the planet. To better understand the dynamics and predictability of this system, an interdisciplinary team of climate scientists and data analytics experts collaborated with the goal of: (1) advancing the frontier of climate predictability and predictive analytics, and (2) advancing the field of data science by bringing challenges from climate applications that require new theoretical developments. Through this project the group made advancements in key areas ranging from improving seasonal precipitation and wildfire predictability to multiscale space-time uncertainty quantification for remotely sensed precipitation products.

 

Seasonal precipitation predictability is crucial for water resources management and decision analysis, especially in drought prone regions of the world. We used a combination of physics-based models and advanced machine-learning methods to understand precipitation predictability. In one approach we developed a novel algorithm known as Graph Total Variation (GTV) which accounts for space-time dependencies in the predictor variables for dimensionality reduction and improved predictive skill. We applied the GTV methodology for prediction of seasonal precipitation in Southwestern US (SWUS) and demonstrated its superiority over a range of alternative methods. In a complementary approach we also developed a new methodology, called rotated spectral Principal Component Analysis (rsPCA), for identifying dynamical modes of variability in climate systems at a range of scales of interest and demonstrated its robustness and advantages over existing methods in capturing propagating modes. We applied the rsPCA to track the Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO) in observations and climate model outputs and showed that MJO variability is substantially underestimated in most CMIP6 models.

 

Satellite-based sensors form a critical part of the observational infrastructure for monitoring precipitation across the globe, particularly in regions sparse in ground-based gages. We utilized advanced data analytics to evaluate the performance of various satellite-based precipitation products. In particular, we developed a new prognostic spectral error model (in Fourier or wavelet domain) which acknowledges the state-dependent and scale-dependent nature of the uncertainty in remote sensing retrievals of precipitation and also the dependencies between the target variable and the retrieval errors. We introduced the concept of “effective resolution” defined as the finest scale at which the spectral signal to noise ratio is higher than 1, and at which scale the accuracy of the products is sufficient for hydrologic applications. We also explored how the choice of the objective function influences the performance of ML algorithms for precipitation retrieval, showing that incorporating advanced probabilistic based metrics into the objective function can improve retrievals of extreme precipitation, which has implications for flood and hazard management.

 

Lastly, changing wildfire regimes in the western US and other fire-prone regions pose considerable risks to human health and ecosystem function. However, our understanding of wildfire behavior is still limited by a lack of data products that systematically quantify fire spread, behavior and impacts. We developed ML methodologies for the prediction of wildfire spread, understanding the climatic and geomorphic controls on the final fire size, and a global forecast system for fire emission estimation using climate variables. This has significant implications for wildfire management across the globe.
